text: today on the caucus john harwood and
Jeff Zeleny discussed fundraising for
the 2012 election also mark Landler on
the politics behind President Obama's
upcoming address to the nation on
Afghanistan Jeff we've got nine days
left before the end of the second
quarter and a few days after that
candidates are going to show how much
money they've raised is the campaign at
this point much more about donors than
is about voters it is about donors at
this point because this is a pivotal
time for candidates to show that they
are strong enough to go forward in the
summer months the frontrunners like Mitt
Romney he is trying to present himself
as the inevitable frontrunner course he
is a network to happen to from four
years ago Mitt Romney is going to exceed
everyone else you know perhaps as much
as three times as much and for the next
you know a week or so that's his key
focus Jon Huntsman entered the race
yesterday he has an overlapping profile
with Mitt Romney how much can he cut
into Romney's financial base how much
does he need to he's trying to pick off
some of these Romney supporters who are
not quite yet signed on with Governor
Romney this time around both of those
guys are really rich why does it matter
so much whether they raise money from
other people can't they write their own
checks it matters because that's a sign
of support if someone is willing to give
money or to ask their friends to give
money it's a sign of support that
they're invested in their candidate so
it's actually part of the campaign
process it's not just to make sure that
you can have TV ads at the end of the
day it's not just the dollar sign it's
who's writing these checks because that
signifies that they're going to vote for
you their friends are going to vote for
you and you actually have a reservoir of
support talk about tim pawlenty he had a
difficult debate a week ago he has
struggled to raise money by most of the
accounts that we've seen he's playing
big in Iowa which means he's got to
spend a lot of money on the Iowa straw
poll how serious are his problems
flowing out of money his financial
problems are serious he's having a very
hard time raising money we're told all
these reports are due on July fifteenth
that is going to be a tough week a tough
day for governor pawlenty he'll have a
fairly rocky summer here a very lean
summer he has a lot of campaign
consultants and advice
around him he may have to shave some of
those off but remember at John McCain
was completely out of money four years
ago John Kerry in 2004 until he lent
himself some money absolutely the
history books are filled with people who
have have struggled and it's how you
come out of this adversity now let me
ask you about a couple of other
candidates michelle bachman who is
playing and competing with tim pawlenty
in iowa had a very good debate she's
shown in house races at least the
capacity to raise an awful lot of money
what does that mean for her prospects in
the race and on the flip side Newt
Gingrich has seen his campaign sort of
dissolve and some fundraising aides have
most recently quit does that mean that
he's cooked I think with congresswoman
Bachmann she's always raised this money
because of one thing she's always said
that you know elect me send me money I
will stop Nancy Pelosi now this
fundraising is going to be more about
her oh sounds easy thing it's not as
easy but she'll still raise a fair bit
of money I have no question about that
at all Newt Gingrich we're hearing again
reports of how his camp his presidential
campaign may be up to almost a million
dollars in debt he is going to become a
marginalized candidate if this continues
let me ask you finally about Barack
Obama there's talk that he could raise a
billion dollars in this campaign do we
think that President Obama is going to
have a clear and significant fundraising
advantage over whoever the Republican
nominee is or is it safe to assume that
when somebody emerges from that
Republican field they're going to be
plenty well funded to compete with this
Democratic president I think in the end
they will be plenty well funded but not
at the beginning whichever Republican
candidate emerges as the nominee is
likely going to finish the primary
season if it's early or late without
much money on hand and that's when the
Obama campaign is going to jump in and
use that window you know from a late
spring to the conventions and really
begin to hammer them but at the end of
the day most of the money is fairly
equal especially when you factor in
outside groups the 1 billion dollar
figure has been thrown around mainly by
Republicans because they're using that
as an incentive to raise money the
billion dollar figure is probably
inflated but it'll be a lot of money
President Obama will announce a
significant reduction of troops in
Afghanistan and a speech from the White
House this evening and while we don't
know the precise details of what the
president is going to lay out the belief
is that he will announce that the entire
30,000 troops from the surge of December
09 will be returned to the United States
within about 18 months or by the end of
2012 this announcement will have complex
implications for the president
politically on Capitol Hill which has
grown weary of the war but is splitting
in its response to what should be done
in unusual ways in the Republican Party
you have both traditional hawkish
Republicans like Senator John McCain who
would like to leave as many combat
troops in Afghanistan for as long as
possible but you also have members of
the Tea Party who have a more of an
isolationist streak and an intense focus
on the budgetary impact of the war
they'd like to withdraw on a wholesale
basis as soon as we can and similarly in
the Democratic Party you have an
anti-war left which would like to pull
out of afghanistan altogether and a more
moderate contingent symbolized by
senators like John Kerry who also want
to bring home troops but on a more
measured scale so this is breaking up
political lines in Washington in
interesting ways and has all kinds of
implications as well for President Obama
as he enters an election year in which
some Republicans are staking out
positions on the war that are actually
to the left of the president similarly
in his relationship with the Pentagon
the president is walking a line between
demanding a reduction that's deep enough
to satisfy budgetary and political
pressures on the hill while not putting
the generals in a position of pulling
out so many troops that they feel that
they can't consolidate the gains they've
made on the battlefield over the past 18
months so it'll be a somewhat of a
balancing act for the president and some
people have said that will know that
he's got the balance right if nobody's
happy with the decision he announces
you
